data.title: Fix SpriteEffect half pixel offset
data.body:
Now that we've made `SpriteEffect` public we have to make sure it works.

Currently you can see it is always applying a half pixel offset... even on platforms that don't require it:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Effect/SpriteEffect.cs#L62

It should use the `SpriteBatch.NeedsHalfPixelOffset` flag like `SpriteBatch` does:
 https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/SpriteBatch.cs#L140

While we're at it we should add in a unit test for it since we need to ensure it works now.

data.title: Linux Installer: Snaps or Flatpak
data.body:
I will be doing an update of Linux installer for MG 3.7. Now the current way it's set up is that it uses a .run installer, and it requires a lot of stuff to be the latest version. I can't do much about it and there isn't any backwards compatibility, like for almost all of the distro specific packages. Now in recent months 2 projects have appeared which aren't distro specific and offer backwards compatibility, these 2 projects are: 
- Snaps - http://snapcraft.io/
- Flatpak (aka Xdg-app) - http://flatpak.org/

Now one of these should be selected, if anyone has a valid reason to select one over the other, do mention it bellow. Also please avoid selecting one of them because you like one of the contributors of the projects.

data.title: Silently catching rumble init errors
data.body:
Following #4928, it turns out that `Sdl.Haptic.RumbleInit` can raise the same error despite passing the rumble test... (e.g. with Logitech F710 gamepads).
This PR silently catches init errors and closes the haptic device to continue normally without rumble.

cc @cra0zy @tomspilman

data.title: D3Dcompiler_43.dll missing
data.body:
For a developer running Windows 10 who clones MonoGame for the first time... everything appears to build and runs correctly. But if you try to build an effect in the pipeline tool it will fail with "D3Dcompiler_43.dll missing" unless you have installed the DX Runtime package. 

Surely we can do better than this.

Ideas...
1. Change the message you see in build output to "Could not locate DX9 dll's. Install the DX Runtime Package (https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=35&nowin10)".
2. Include this as a dependency alongside sharpdx (which is who is actually trying to load it).
3. Allow using DX11 to compile shaders.

data.title: Fixing GL calling conventions for win32
data.body:
Fixes #4929 

On Windows, `CallingConvention` for OpenGL has to be `Winapi`, while it has to be `Cdecl` on Unix systems. Thankfully these are the default values on the .NET CLR and Mono running on Unix, and can therefore be safely removed.

This PR also fixes the signature of `GL.DepthRange()`.

cc @tomspilman

data.title: Remove restriction on HardwareModeSwitch
data.body:
The HardwareModeSwitch property controls if the game window
goes into hard full screen or into a 'soft' fullscreen (which
is basically a fullscreen borderless form).

There is a use case where the developer might want to allow
the user the ability to switch between the two. Plus I cannot
see any hardware reason why this cannot be changed at runtime.

data.title: Fix Mouse updating when moving the Window

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
When you click and hold the title bar of the window
and move it around we are still updating the X/Y
location of the Mouse. This does not happen in XNA
and it makes things look a bit weird as far as the
user is concerned.

This commit just moves the updating of the X/Y position
into the check that the mouse has Focus. This fixes the
issue since when we click on the Title bar the Mouse does
NOT have focus.

data.title: Fix DirectX backbuffer resize behavior

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
The resize behavior on the WindowsDX build is incorrect:

![munch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/15982524/03330b8e-2f50-11e6-93d3-6123f85d66f4.PNG)

The top image is the code under XNA, the middle is the new Desktop GL with SDL2, and the bottom is Windows DX.

What is happening is the Windows DX build is not resizing the back buffer to match the client area of the window.  You can see XNA and the GL version of MonoGame do this correctly.

I'm just setting `Window.AllowUserResizing = true;` in the `Game` constructor and using this to scale the scene to fit the window:

```
                var screenHeight = GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferHeight;
                var screenWidth = GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth;
```

data.title: Shader parameter initialization lost after building glsl
data.body: I was doing some rendering with a custom shader (built from the pipeline tool) in a DesktopGL project and my models were all black. It all worked in DirectX. After a while of being horribly frustrated I found out my parameters were not initialized, so I checked out the xnb. Turns out the initialization of parameters in a shader gets lost when it's translated to glsl. Is that a MojoShader thing? Can we fix this?

data.title: BGR bitmap swapped red and blue channels
data.body:
I wanted to set up a little sandbox project to mess around in, and tried to load and draw the Icon bitmap that comes with the template. The result is this 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14875382/15963462/88e75f16-2f12-11e6-90ac-4f34926d8139.png)
Opening in a text editor, I see BGR in front so I guess that's the format it's in, but it's interpreted by MG as RGB. I set the textureformat in the pipeline tool to color, since that only seems to say something about compression, it doesn't imply RGBA, right? After debugging a bit I found out FreeImage gets the channel masks as 

```
R: 11111111 00000000 00000000, G: 00000000 11111111 00000000, B: 00000000 00000000 11111111
```

Now that's wrong right? Shouldn't this figure out the right masks based on the header? @KonajuGames

data.title: Fixes logical buffer store when swapping the default framebuffer (iOS)
data.body:
Discards the depth/stencil attached to the main framebuffer (if any) to avoid a [logical buffer store](https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/3DDrawing/Conceptual/OpenGLES_ProgrammingGuide/WorkingwithEAGLContexts/WorkingwithEAGLContexts.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40008793-CH105-SW7) operation when the main framebuffer is swapped.
This also adds proper depth/stencil initialization based on the value of `GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredDepthFormat`.

data.title: [DesktopGL] Crash if 2 (or more) gamepads are plugged
data.body:
Hello,

Following @endimilojkoski findings, I can confirm that DesktopGL crashes if more than one gamepads are plugged.

The crash happens here: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/Joystick.SDL.cs#L17

SDL events seem to return the same DeviceID (always 0) for all gamepads plugged, hence the `Joystick.SDL.Joysticks` and  `GamePad.SDL.Gamepads` dictionaries are already populated with the same key-value pair.

cc @cra0zy (I'll try to take a look at this today if I have some time, I remember fixing the very same issue in OpenTK back then, or just let me know if you already started to work on it)
